Yeah at first this is kind of counterintuitive. It seems like what you were visualizing at first is more like a simplicial complex, and those were invented first for a reason.

Degenerate simplices are simplices that are 'flattened' -- they have at least one edge that is from a point to the same point. This only makes sense relative to a simplicial set they are contained in, i.e. not for the abstract simplicial simplices. A simplex can only be degenerate if it is a specific simplex in a simplicial set.

The degeneracy maps make, for each k-simplex S, k different degenerate k+1-simplices, putting the extra degenerate edge on each possible vertex. Every face of each of these degenerate simplices is either a degenerate simplex "over" a face of S, or S itself (twice). The mixed simplicial identities communicate this.

These identities communicate the shape of a simplex -- the way that its faces are all glued together to form its boundary.
It probably helps to draw everything, first for a triangle and then for a tetrahedron.
Topology is after all about space, so it's good to actually see what's going on in examples.

Leopold Schlicht said:

By the way, it seems the definition of a simplicial set allows one to glue simplices together "in the wrong dimension". For instance, I could glue two triangles together at one vertex. Also, what seems to be possible is to glue a triangle on a tetrahedron. This seems weird. Is this really allowed?

Yes, it's really allowed. It may seem weird when you do this in isolation, but it's necessary to allow some really basic constructions to exist. For example, if you glue 6 triangles to form a hexagon, many of the pairs are glued just at a corner.

In general, though, simplicial sets don't represent only spaces of uniform dimension like manifolds, but can represent a much greater variety of spaces, or other things entirely like categories.

... except with arrows on all the edges, etc.
Here we aren't drawing the degenerate simplexes, but you have to remember that they are there!

An n-simplex has n+1 faces; each face differs from each other by the inclusion of one single vertex. Each face is glued to each of the others along its own face that does not include the differing vertex. There is a nice consistent numbering for faces where the facet that glues the i-th face to the j-the face is the i-th face of the j-th face and the j-1-th face of the i-th face. This is a good thing to work out on the triangle and the tetrahedron.

A degenerate simplex is "flat" or "flattened" in that it has a face that includes every vertex of the entire simplex. It is, for example, a triangle with only 2 distinct vertices, so that it is collapsed into a line, or a tetrahedron with only 3 distinct vertices, so that it is collapsed into a triangle. There are other equivalent characterizations, like 'it has 2 faces that are the same simplex'.

Also, I think you have a good intuition for simplicial complexes, not semisimplicial sets, since you are having trouble with the numbering and orientation of faces, which are the main distinctions between simplicial complexes and semisimplicial sets.

@Leopold Schlicht I will respond to your question with my answer for why the representable functor y([n])y([n])y([n]) is the 'right' choice of representative for the nnn simplex Δn\Delta^nΔn. I also answer your question "why are the degenerate simplices there" by explaining that they play a strong role wrt products - the product of semisimplicial sets does not represent the geometric Cartesian product of the associated complexes, but the product of simplicial sets does, and the difference comes down to degeneracies.

This is a bit of an abstract answer so it might be too high level for this concrete situation but there's a general theorem of category theory that says the following.

Let MMM be a small category, and let CCC be a category with all small colimits. Let F:M→CF : M\to CF:M→C be a functor. For the concrete case that follows, I am interested in the case where MMM is the simplex category, and CCC is the category of topological spaces, and FFF sends the ordinal [n]=0..n[n]={0..n}[n]=0..n to Δn\Delta^{n}Δn, which is the convex hull of n+1n+1n+1 points in a real vector space in general position.

For any presheaf PPP on MMM, we can construct the "weighted colimit"" of FFF with weights in PPP (also known as the "Indexed colimit" in some older literature. This is a gluing construction which is built out of taking ∣P(m)∣|P(m)|∣P(m)∣ many copies of F(m)F(m)F(m) for each object mmm in MMM, and gluing these together along the maps of the diagram FFF in a way specified by the maps of PPP. In this way we can interpret presheaves on MMM as combinatorial schemas for gluing together the objects in the diagram FFF along the maps of FFF; i.e. interpreting the objects F(m)F(m)F(m) as basic building blocks, out of which we can construct more complex objects.

If FFF is regarded as fixed and PPP is allowed to vary, then this defines a functor from presheaves on MMM to CCC which sends each presheaf PPP to the weighted colimit of FFF with weights in PPP; it sends each combinatorial schema to the thing it describes in CCC.

This functor, which I call the "realization" RRR (see the nlab page on nerve-realization for more on this) has some interesting theoretical properties. RRR is in a precise sense a canonical choice of extension of F:M→CF: M\to CF:M→C along the Yoneda embedding y:M→M^y : M\to \hat{M}y:M→M^, it is the "left Kan extension" of FFF along yyy, and we have a natural isomorphism R∘y≅FR\circ y \cong FR∘y≅F. RRR is the unique colimit-preserving functor such that R∘y≅FR\circ y\cong FR∘y≅F. We can interpret this as follows. Each presheaf PPP on MMM can be written in a canonical way as the colimit of representable presheaves. This is known as the Density theorem, and it is a corollary of the Yoneda lemma. Since we ask that for every representable presheaf y(m)y(m)y(m), R(y(m))≅F(m)R(y(m))\cong F(m)R(y(m))≅F(m) naturally in mmm, and RRR preserves colimits, it follows that for an arbitrary presheaf PPP, R(P)R(P)R(P) should be glued together out of the objects F(m)F(m)F(m) in precisely the same way that PPP itself is to be glued together out of the representable presheaves y(m)y(m)y(m) as prescribed by the Density lemma.

So, to answer your question "why do we let y(n)y(n)y(n) represent Δn+1\Delta^{n+1}Δn+1, my answer to this is that the isomorphism R∘y≅FR\circ y\cong FR∘y≅F tells us that there is a canonical choice of presheaf PPP as combinatorial schema such that R(P)≅F(m)R(P)\cong F(m)R(P)≅F(m); namely we should take P=y(m)P=y(m)P=y(m). Thus the representable functor y([n])y([n])y([n]) is the canonical choice of presheaf whose realization is Δn\Delta^nΔn.

As for the degenerate simplices, surely others have explained this in the thread or you've seen this in the literature but the most immediately accessible technical reason why we care about degenerate simplices is that if σ\sigmaσ is degenerate in XnX_nXn​ and τ\tauτ is degenerate in YnY_nYn​, it is not necessarily the case that the pair (σ,τ)(\sigma,\tau)(σ,τ) is degenerate in (X×Y)n=Xn×Yn(X\times Y)_n = X_n\times Y_n(X×Y)n​=Xn​×Yn​. Here is an exercise in combinatorics to help you understand this fact: call a simplex maximal nondegenerate if it is nondegenerate and it is not the face of any other nondegenerate simplex. If you can explicitly describe the maximal nondegenerate simplices of a simplicial set then you have a good sense of what its geometric realization should look like. For example, it is easy to see that y([n])y([n])y([n]) has one and only one maximal nondegenerate
simplex, namely the identity map [n]→[n][n]\to [n][n]→[n] in degree nnn. Prove that the maximal nondegenerate simplices of the product complex y([p])×y([q])y([p])\times y([q])y([p])×y([q]) are all concentrated in degree p+qp+qp+q and are in one-to-one correspondence with (p,q)(p,q)(p,q) shuffles. (There could be a minor typo here in that it should really be (p+1,q+1)(p+1,q+1)(p+1,q+1) shuffles or something of this ilk.)

The category of semisimplicial sets has categorical products. But these products are not geometrically meaningful. These products do not really represent the product of the complexes in Top they describe. Another way to say this is that the realization functor from semisimplicial sets to Top does not preserve products. It is easy to see why this is the case. The product of a ppp dimensional thing and a qqq dimensional thing is a p+qp+qp+q dimensional thing. But for semisimplicial sets XXX and YYY σ\sigmaσ is a ppp-simplex in XXX and τ\tauτ is a qqq simplex in YYY, there is no obvious element of the product semisimplicial set X×YX\times YX×Y which represents the pair (σ,τ)(\sigma,\tau)(σ,τ). Where in the product semisimplicial set X×YX\times YX×Y can we see the product of these cells? On the other hand if σ∈Xn\sigma\in X_nσ∈Xn​ and τ∈Yn\tau\in Y_nτ∈Yn​ then the pair (σ,τ)(\sigma,\tau)(σ,τ) is a well defined member of (X×Y)n=Xn×Yn(X\times Y)_n= X_n\times Y_n(X×Y)n​=Xn​×Yn​. But this is not geometrically meaningful. The product of σ,τ\sigma,\tauσ,τ should be 2n2n2n dimensional, not nnn dimensional. It is not easy to see how to interpret the meaining of the pair (σ,τ)(\sigma,\tau)(σ,τ) in X×YX\times YX×Y.

But if XXX and YYY are simplicial, rather than semi-simplicial sets, something incredible becomes possible. Degeneracies allow a simplex that, intuitively, is ppp dimensional, to masquerade for formal purposes as a simplex of arbitrarily high dimension. Thus if σ∈Xp\sigma\in X_pσ∈Xp​ and τ\tauτ is in YqY_qYq​, then we may repeatedly apply degeneracy maps to σ,τ\sigma,\tauσ,τ respectively until we get elements σ′,τ′\sigma',\tau'σ′,τ′ in Xp+q,Yp+qX_{p+q},Y_{p+q}Xp+q​,Yp+q​ respectively. Then the pair (σ′,τ′)(\sigma',\tau')(σ′,τ′) in (X×Y)p+q(X\times Y)_{p+q}(X×Y)p+q​ is a thing of the "right dimension". Actually there are many different possible choices of ways to write x,yx,yx,y as degenerate p+qp+qp+q cells x′,y′x',y'x′,y′; together all these degenerate cells represent a triangulation of the product Δp×Δq\Delta^p\times\Delta^qΔp×Δq. To see what I am saying, I encourage you to calculate by hand the geometric realization of y([1])×y([1])y([1])\times y([1])y([1])×y([1]) and see that it is a square, and y([1])×y([2])y([1])\times y([2])y([1])×y([2]) and see that it describes a triangular prism.

As a consequence of this. the geometric realization functor from simplicial sets to topological spaces preserves products up to handwaving about the distinction between Top and CGHaus, CGWH or some other good category of well behaved topological spaces

I see that you say you have read the literature but i continue to learn more about simplicial sets every day by reading the literature. Just today I came across Kan's paper which demonstrates that the homotopy groups of any space or simplicial set can be expressed as the homology groups of a certain chain complex of not-necessarily Abelian groups. This reduces homotopy to homology. Interestingly one also has the theorem of Dold-Thom which shows that homology of a space XXX can be reduced to the homotopy groups of a space S(X)S(X)S(X), so the two notions are intertranslateable.
There's been a lot written about simplicial sets. I recommend reading the first few sections of Manin and Gelfand's Methods of Homological Algebra for their treatment of simplicial sets and geometric realization.

But the reason edges in a simplicial set have a direction is that each edge eee has a specified "starting-point" d1(e)d_1(e)d1​(e) and "ending-point" d0(e)d_0(e)d0​(e)

Leopold Schlicht said:

John Baez said:

Here we aren't drawing the degenerate simplexes, but you have to remember that they are there!

But why are they there?

Because for a simplicial set we have n+1n+1n+1 maps called "degeneracies" from its set of nnn-simplices to its set of (n+1)(n+1)(n+1)-simplices. This is just part of the definition. So, for example, each 1-simplex (or "edge") gives rise to two 2-simplexes (or "triangles"), and each 2-simplex (or "triangle") gives rise to three 3-simplexes (or "tetrahedra"), and so on.

As a result, every simplicial set except the empty simplicial set has, for all nnn, a nonempty set of nnn-simplexes. But we in examples don't draw most of these, because we don't draw the degenerate ones.

You can draw the degenerate ones, and you need to learn how to understand this stuff. Nick Hu said:

My intuition says that in all the face/degeneracy maps in the terminal simplicial set should be unique.

As I mentioned, the terminal simplicial set has one n-simplex for each n. This follows from a general fact about presheaf categories: the terminal presheaf has "one thing of each kind".

As a consequence, there's no choice about what the face and degeneracy maps can be in the terminal simplicial set: they're all maps from a one-element set to a one-element set .

As a further consequence, all these maps are isomorphisms. Indeed, they obey all possible well-formed equations, e.g. all degeneracy maps from n-simplices to (n+1)-simplices are equal.
So yes: in the terminal simplicial set "all parallel maps consisting entirely of face and degeneracy maps are equal"... because all parallel maps are equal.

But it's certainly not true in a general simplicial set that "all parallel maps consisting entirely of face and degeneracy maps are equal". That's why we have different names for ∂0\partial_0∂0​ and ∂1\partial_1∂1​, for example: they're parallel, but not equal.

Regarding the simplicial identities:

A good way to get to learn, grasp, and love them is to write them as commutative squares. (They are all squares, except those that state that a degeneracy map is a section to its adjacent face maps.)

The immediate benefit is that the ambiguity is eliminated and one can clearly see what are the domain and codomain of each face or degeneracy map. (It also helps figuring out what are the valid indices for a given simplicial identity -- and it helps figuring out if didjd_i d_jdi​dj​ means 'first did_idi​ then djd_jdj​' or the other way around!)

Furthermore, squares can be pasted! This shows how the simplicial identities can be combined to yield further identities. Often these further identities are important in applications. The ones called 'simplicial identities' are only a minimal generating set of identities.

Another benefit is that in applications to category theory it is important to demand some of these squares to be pullback squares -- a condition not so easy to express with algebraic identities. Most importantly, the Segal condition, which characterises categories among all simplicial sets, states that simplicial-identity squares with top face maps against bottom face maps are pullbacks. (There are actually several other classes of simplicial-identity squares that are important to know are pullbacks, characterising various properties of simplicial sets, e.g. split, stiff, complete, and the decomposition-space property. Or one can demand only a weak pullback property, as done in the recent paper Weak cartesian properties of simplicial sets by Carme Constantin, Tobias Fritz, Paolo Perrone, and Brandon Shapiro, motivated by probability theory.)

Finally, when dealing with simplicial groupoids or simplicial categories, it is often necessary to consider pseudo-simplicial objects. Here the simplicial identities hold only up to specified isomorphims, and these have to be specified as part of the data and are required to satisfy coherence conditions. The isomorphisms are 2-cells occupying the simplicial-identity squares, and the coherence constraints are expressed in terms of pasting of squares. (A simplicial-identity style presentation of these coherence laws were worked out by Rick Jardine 30 years ago in a paper called Supercoherence. There are 17 laws! But once you regard the simplicial identities as squares, the coherence laws are just cubes.)

The simplicial identities make much more sense if you think of an nnn simplex as a length nnn list of points. There's a notion in category theory of a "weighted colimit". If CCC is a category, F:C→DF : C\to DF:C→D is a functor, and $$P : C^{\rm op}\to \mathbf{Sets}$ is a presheaf, then one can define the "weighted colimit of FFF with weights in PPP". The idea is that the weighted colimit should be built by gluing together copies of F(c)F(c)F(c) with multiplicity given by ∣P(c)∣|P(c)|∣P(c)∣. All gluings are along the maps of the diagram FFF, but the question of which copies of F(c)F(c)F(c) are glued to which copies of F(d)F(d)F(d) along the map F(f)F(f)F(f) is answered by the presheaf map P(f):P(d)→P(c)P(f): P(d)\to P(c)P(f):P(d)→P(c). These two argument limits are pretty interesting and expressive and a very useful general notion of gluing.

Imo pretty much all notions of "simplicial complex" I know of are adequately treated by this framework. Take DDD to be the category Top\mathbf{Top}Top. Take CCC to be a category whose objects are the various simplices Δ0,Δ1\Delta^0, \Delta^1Δ0,Δ1 and so on, and whose maps are some interesting class of linear maps between them along which we want to allow simplices to be glued. The class of linear maps could be all linear maps sending vertices to vertices, or only the ones that respect the ordering of the vertices, or only the injective ones, and so on. There are various possible choices and each will give rise to a slightly different notion of simplicial complex - if F:C→DF: C\to DF:C→D is the inclusion functor into Top, simplicial complexes are weighted colimits of FFF with coefficients in some presheaf.

There is a notion of "abstract simplicial complex" which isn't obviously of this form, but it's not hard to see that abstract simplicial complexes are a reflexive subcategory of the symmetric simplicial sets.
